review_title: Good company, questionable management in some branches
job_title: Administrative in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Worked with the company for five years, from the hospital to the home health division. The hospital part was wonderful. Employees frequently given lovely, thoughtful gifts from the company. Health insurance was amazing , still miss it. Great working environment where you really felt like the company appreciated its employees.
cons: Terrible management within the home health care branch of the health care system. I worked with the company for five years, with zero disciplinary actions against me (not even so much as a verbal warning) and no call offs. Within less than a year of transferring to the home health side, I was given a written warning because I could not provide policy documentation to a regulatory agency. I could not provide the documentation, because top leadership did not even have the documentation in place until several days AFTER the incident. The vice president angrily drove four hours to my satellite office, to reprimand and write me up for not having a document that didn't exist. The vice president blamed the lowest level employee for not possessing a document that did not exist (not even a rough draft!!) that he was responsible for creating and distributing.

cons: So many cons- coming from 15 years of being with CCPN - -Micromanaging by certain managers like they are on a power trip -Upper Management taking the patient’s side with a complaint over the employee’s side -Unfair expectations of extra work to try and fit in one work day -HIGH turnover rate to which upper management turns their heads to, doesn’t address the real problem -Staff scared to complain because manager is friends with so many other people in the system and there is passive aggressive retaliation -Offices / clinics allowed to operate how the providers want despite policy even if it means safety and osha compliance are ignored -Providers can’t manage their time and when they get overwhelmed and behind during the day, they take it out on the clinical staff as if they are the sole reason that they aren’t ready to leave by 5pm. -Gossip is bad in the clinics -Raises just got bumped to 5%, but you top out around year 8 so unless you go back to school for your RN, or promote to Clinical coordinator you are stuck. -All leave comes out of PTO allowance. No separate sick pay or vacation pay. And company holidays also come out if that allowance. -Hard to move up with out “knowing somebody” -Clinic nurses feel like the “red headed step child” compared to the medical center nurses in regards to employee appreciation, nurse’s week. -Bullying by managers, doctors is overlooked, ignored by upper management and HR.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The work being done at Cook Children's is truly life-changing. It's gratifying to be part of an organization that focuses on the physical and emotional well-beings of patients and their families. Retirement plan is exceptional and healthcare plans are reasonably priced.
cons: Boundaries between leadership, management, and other employees are extremely stratified. In my experience, there was no such as an open-door policy. Certain departments are very political which makes for toxic situations. In extreme scenarios, leadership is often unwilling to confront these issues through HR for two reasons: HR is not considered effective because they have failed to appropriately handle past situations, and these situations often stem from the managers' own lack of leadership or toxic behavior. Even when teams have extremely high turnover, it is unheard of for HR to intervene or make inquiries about the situation. For a young professional, there are few opportunities for growth within the system. The reason for this appears to be twofold: longtime employees are hesitant to leave, and ageism. I witnessed several young, female employees leave their positions because they were simply burnt out from the emotional labor they were expected to perform daily. They were scrutinized for their appearances (especially their dress) and demeanors and faced bullying from senior female employees. Certain departments lack any diversity and are actively unwilling to discuss the issue, much less act.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Loved my job, patients, and families 
Excellent manager
Felt apart of a family. Amazing, nice, and wonderful coworkers. Hospital staff and patient care staff were always friendly, helpful, and truly care about you. 
Cooperate is not included, they stink.
Great benefits
Truly believe that treatments and care for patients is of the highest quality. 
Beautiful campus inside and out
Many resources for patients and families. Child life team is amazing, There are so many innovative things and cool thing to do and see there, for patients and families. 
Starbucks, Chick-fil-A, frozen yogurt shop, cafeteria, and hours that allow night shift to get food too.
cons:
Base pay was the companies minimum pay, $13.15, PCTs paid minimum, and work just as hard if not harder than the nurses. No apperception celebration days or opportunities for incentive bonus pay for extra shifts when hospital is at capacity. The new company minimum pay is now $18.25 only because uou must be fully Covid vaccinated to work at Cook’s, you will not be hired if you aren’t vaccinated, that’s why the pay is much better now, but I believe PCTs should receive higher than the minimum pay, and it infuriated me that the unit seceretary who had no degrees or certificates made much more than PCTs did. PCTS are required to do much more, harder work, have education, experience, hold a license, and are heavily involved in patient care, which can be sometimes quite heartbreaking, emotionally exhausting, or physically demanding/painful. I’ve had several injuries from patients, and even parents: all the secretaries get paid more for less than half of the work we do. Cooperate/Company can be greedy, sneaky, and uncaring, we joke about them being the best for profit ‘non-profit’: They take credit for our hard work, and don’t acknowledge us. Policies made by people who never work with patients made the job 20 times worse.
Can be hard to get a position here

job_title: RN, MSN in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Working with children
Tuition reimbursement
Starbucks...when it's open.
cons:
-The little people (bedside nursing) that keep the place afloat don't seem to matter as much as upper admin or those that don't work the bedside anymore. You are always replaceable.
-It's about WHO you know, not what you know or what you do.
-Pay is 6-10% less than surrounding hospitals and Dallas Children's so it's pretty much the same level of work for way less pay. They also won't pay any market adjustments to keep up with the rising expenses of living in or around DFW.
-Don't offer float pay or critical care pay when sent to critical care units, but ICU nurses continue to get their differential when floating to med surg units.
-Emotional/mental abuse bedside care staff deal with from families and other staff is never addressed appropriately by management. There are a lot of biases in favor of those that have worked there a long time or families that are friends with executive personnel.
-It's a business first like most hospitals, patient safety is not always a priority when it comes to saving money. 
-You don't really get to use the PTO you earn if your plans interfere with low staffing or managers vacation/time off.
-Essentially, it's like any other hospital so don't think that because it's for children that's it a better place to work.

review_title: What Once Was Great, No Longer the Case
job_title: Applications Systems Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Miracles performed daily for the patients and their families.  The resources for them have no end - as it should be!
cons: Favoritism and bias abound.  No accountability for Leadership.  People who have been around the organization long enough should remember what the culture was like.  That culture needs to return.  The morale has plummeted and made it impossible to "feel good" about working there.  The Medical Center was always a whole different place, but IT is not treated the same way.  The "processes" you're asked to follow are only imposed on some, not others.  Some are punished for non-existent "reasons".  Complaints are not taken to heart.  Once a person is perceived as weak or annoying, they get on a corrective action plan.  I watched it done to so many people who were powerless to stop it.  The things that were written about them in these actions plans that they were forced to sign was truly sad.  The fact that they "care" for children and mistreat their parents who work there shows that they are only concerned about one thing - money.

review_title: Best Company I  Have Ever Worked For
job_title: Registered Nurse in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
There is overtime but no required OT 
The managers really do care about their employees
You get out of it what you give. There is always the availability to advance your career here. On the flip side...if you simply want to come to work, get paid, and go home, that is an option, too.
The patients are AMAZING. Who doesn't want to work with these babies?!
The pay is appropriate for the area (if not above average).
Bonuses when money is available for employees
While other companies in the area are downsizing their staff amid COVID-19, our management is taking care of it's employees and working tirelessly to work with funds to ensure no employee goes without.
I really can't say enough about working for Cook Children's. They really are an amazing company to work for.
cons: The only con I can think of is that the managers really do work hard to keep their employees once they are hired. This doesn't sound like a con until you have an employee that sits around doing nothing all shift while others are taking up the slack.

job_title: in Fort Worth, TX
pros: CCHCS has good benefits and competitive salary.
cons: The Information Services Department has a top - down leadership breakdown. The Senior Leadership there does not listen to the staff level personnel nor do they listen to their immediate managers when there are issues brought to their attention. They rather ignore the issue, allow things to escalate and then the GOOD people pay the price. They ignore the bigger issue, the root issue and do not look into or investigate when problems arise. They rather run the employees/staff into the ground without blinking an eye and do not have any compassion for the staff. The staff are treated like cattle rather than people. This is not always the way the department was but the last several years it has come to this point. I hate to see a single department be such a negative and hostile atmosphere for an overall great company.

job_title: LVN in Fort Worth, TX
pros: I love caring for the patients coming into the office. They can bring a smile to my face no matter how bad of a day it is.
cons: Harassment and favoritism are incredibly prevalent in the clinics. Managers will preach teamwork while turning employees against one another. Upper management is well aware of what’s going on and despite multiple complaints by multiple employees they continue to let it happen. I have also been told by multiple people (managers and providers) that the office and patients should take top priority in my life, above my health, family, etc, and have actually been put in the position of choosing my job or my child as well as coming into work ill despite a doctors note advising otherwise.

review_title: Great culture but management is out of the loop.
job_title: Social Worker in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Staff members on the front line are generally happy to be at work.  The staff you work with daily has your back and will go above and beyond to help.  The facility is amazing-starbuck's, chick-fll-a, etc.
cons: The Directors and Managers have no idea what it is like to work with the patient population because they sit behind a desk all day.  The facility looks amazing inside & outside; however the population served is more than 1/2 Medicaid.  There is an unrealistic expectation that social workers can fix everything-by staff and families.  Many families arrive with their hands out expecting to be fed, clothed and given gas money to get home.  Instead staff need to empower the families to care for their sick child the best they can.

job_title: Information Services in Fort Worth, TX
pros: All team members are encouraged to "walk the talk" focusing on the Promise, Mission and Values.  Leadership frequently recognizes that the organization and facility are great because of the people.  Leadership cares, listens to suggestions and really tries to incorporate feedback into making change when possible.
cons: It is a 24x7x365 environment and it can be difficult at times to achieve a work/life balance.  Leadership and management try to work with team members so there is some flexibility, but at the end of the day, a hospital does at times require team members to "step up" and work some additional hours.  If you are strictly a, "come to work, get a check" mentality, you won't be happy here.  Have to be about something beyond yourself to succeed.

review_title: A truly magical place to work
job_title: Corporate Communications Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
The best part of working at Cook Children's is knowing that every single position makes a difference in the life of a child. I enjoy my position, the people that I work with, and the Promise of the organization. 

The benefits (medical, employee, engagement, etc) are incredible. I literally teared up during New Hire Orientation knowing that my family gets to be a part of this organization and reap its benefits. 

Additionally, I have never been a part of an organization that cares for their employees the way Cook Children's does. When my family was going through a difficult time, I legitimately felt that I had the backing of Cook Children's to walk with me through it. 

Basically, I can not say enough wonderful things about Cook Children's!

review_title: good company if you fit in
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Excellent child life program
Wonderful chaplains and palliative care program
Physician-nurse relationships are the best I have ever experienced. As well as good utilization of nurse practitioners
High level of autonomy for nurses
Many opportunities for learning and development
Nursing councils, committees and opportunities for research
Education assistance
Beautiful hospital with a nail salon for patients
Generous end of the year bonus
They try to help with staffing with incentives
Free parking this is rare for other hospitals
cons:
There are the usual cons of nursing: the EMR, weekend and holiday requirements, and the long wait before switching to days. Benefits aren't as good as they used to be and the yearly raises are only 3%. Implementation of new policies can be confusing.

My main cons are specifically directed to the culture of Cook.

The different units and departments in the hospital to do not get along with each other. It's day shift versus night shift. The ER has issues and complaints with the PI, and the PI complains about the floors. It is not a cohesive environment and staff from different areas can be very rude to each other. It's an "us vs them" mentality.

Specifically in the PI there is a lot of lateral violence. I have seen new orientees and nurse residents get subtly bullied out of the unit and hospital. New employees leave after only a short period of time. 

Many of the nurses in the PI are friends with the managers and have been on the unit for 10+ years and can get away with underhanded aggression. Promotions are based on who you know. Gossip is pervasive and spreads like wildfire. Once a person decides they don't like someone and the rest go along with it. If you're not with the "in crowd" you get treated poorly.

job_title: Child Life Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Small town feel in a big city. Good employee perks and events. Competitive wages.
cons:
Very cliquish. Double standards and micro managing department heads. If you weren't popular in high school, chances are you won't be here either. It feels like stepping back into my high school days of cheerleaders/jocks vs. nerdy smart outcasts. Meetings will be the main thing you'll do no matter what department you are in. These people love meetings. Nothing gets done, but they like to talk about what isn't being done in the meetings. Meetings which are taking up the time you need to get 'said' thing-done! 

I have a feeling that the CEO and CFO have no clue what is actually going on and the Foundation that gathers the donor funding for various programs are equally as clueless. It's a hot mess. They do talk a good game though. You'll be SOLD during orientation. You'll feel proud of working there. Slowly you'll see the unraveling of their propaganda machine and become jaded. It has happened to everyone I know who have worked there, myself included. 

 If you are okay being a drone worker bee and taking orders that make no sense, going to meetings in an echo chamber, then this place is for you.  If you like feeling like you belong to a dysfunctional family that love to be inside your brain at all times, then this place is for you.  

If you like working around a bunch of country bumpkins who are afraid of Muslims and poor people, then this place is for you.  If you want to sit around and talk about your baby and husband instead of doing your job, then this place is definitely for you. If you watch mainstream reality TV shows and think that it matters then apply for the  child life department. It's brimming with idiots who have no idea what is happening in the world around them.  

The parking garage you will  be forced to park in is like playing the game of Risk every morning. There are tons of employee driven events that you can be a part of if you are one of the lucky "cool people" who are invited to participate.  
If you are trying to be a child life specialist because you want to help children, that is great and noble of you but you will not find that at Cook Childrens. Some of the specialist are great, but you won't see them because they are doing their job and everyone else's job. If you are male and reading this, then count yourself out of the race right now. You will never be hired at this company for the child life department. It is clearly a female only club, trust me on this.

review_title: Cook Children's Medical Center, the best working environment in the healthcare industry.
job_title: Paramedic in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
Cook Children's is an excellent place to work. One of the best reasons I enjoy being employed by CCMC is the comraderie among employees. I work in the ED, so it may be different on other floors, but the staff in our unit gets along extremely well. I can not think of one person I do not enjoy working with, and I have never been able to say that about any job I have ever had. Upper level management is visible and accessible, however not to the point of smothering the employee, or appearing to "watch over one's shoulder." Typically no more than about ten days pass between when someone from administration will ask me if I have all of the resources I need to do my job, if there are any process improvements I think could be made. The final question they always ask is how I am PERSONALLY doing. That is a pretty impressive and important question in my opinion, and one that is rarely asked by the administration in other healthcare facilities I have worked at. Being that we see a fair amount of sad cases come through the ED, not all of which have a positive outcome, it is easy to get beaten down sometimes. It is nice to know management and administration care. I have also see many of the suggestions that have been given to management put into action, so it makes the staff feel good that they are not only being heard, but actually being "listened" too. The hospital also gives out gifts almost every quarter for nurses appreciation week, staff birthdays etc. Last year all full time staff got a $500.00 Wal Mart gift card, and part timers got a $250.00 card. The cards were given for no reason other than that the administration really appreciated our hard work and dedication, it was as simple as that. I thought that was really amazing.

The administration has a "blameless" environment attitude towards near misses and other occurrences. This means that unless you were grossly negligent, the hospital will try to fix the reason that the mistake was made, not necessarily punish the person that made it. It also encourages staff to speak up about near misses so process improvements can be made and implemented. 

It is easy to find cliquish groups, especially in the healthcare setting. This is not the case at CCMC. Everyone works together and management promotes a "It's all about the kids" approach to patient centered care and environment. This goes a long way to keep the staff "job focused" and conflict free.
cons: The only downside as of late has been staffing shortages. This is not problem specific to this hospital either, it is nationwide. Management has been trying very creative ways to recruit new staff and retain them, so it is clear that they see the problem and are responding to it. The issue isn't retention so much, but it is the fact that the hospital is growing to keep pace with the size of the community, and they can't seem to find staff fast enough to keep pace. It has been getting better however, and they are still working on the permanent solution.

review_title: Excellent employer until your individuality clashes with someone's pride and ego.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Knowing that you are part of an organization that is REALLY the best place for a sick child to go.  They have the very best doctors and services for all children, even the homeless who cannot pay a penny for their visits, specialists, medicine or surgery.  If I had a sick child, he would go to Cook Children's.  I worked there for four years.  They get 5 stars for the services they provide.
cons: The culture of the hospital, and therefore also of the contractors, is one of a strict hierarchy that allows for NO variation in procedure, or in the comfort level of over-sensitive, self-important individuals that are myopically entrenched in their singular duties.  It's a secretive and back stabbing environment that compliments you for an action on behalf of a child on the one hand, and then undermines your status as an employee for doing the same action with a Cook receptionist or case worker who cannot stand to be questioned about anything.  They are so insecure and mentally fragile that it shakes up their nested position.  So they lash out by reporting offenders to the highest management possible in order to get revenge.  That way, every manager from the top down "knows" what you did.  My manager was VERY supportive and understanding of our higher manager's idiosyncrasies and paranoia, until he fired me in order to stay in good standing with his superiors.  They get 1 star for instilling fear into the employees in order to keep them kissing up.

job_title: Senior Secretary in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Nothing. I wish there was a zero-star option.
cons: Cook Children’s may have a good reputation for being compassionate with their patients, but they treat their employees like dirt. Communication between departments and management is a mess. There were so many things only a select few knew and the rest of us were reprimanded for doing things wrong despite never receiving the correct information in the first place. If you’re a satellite location, it’s even worse. Your facility is just another business opportunity for them. They do not care about off-campus employees at all, to the point of not even knowing what any of us even did and what type of care was given at our facility. You don’t get any paid holidays. Instead, you have one PTO pool (no sick time) that you’re forced to use for holidays, and if you don’t have enough PTO, you just have to go unpaid. You get punished if you call in or leave early, NO MATTER THE CIRCUMSTANCES. I saw people sick as a dog working with children (who are more susceptible to getting sick, mind you) just because they were afraid of being penalized with the punishing and stupid occurrence system Cook Children’s implemented. Even if it’s an emergency (like a death in the family) and you have to leave early, you will be penalized. That’s absolutely heartless and cruel. The pay is also terrible. They pay you under market rate because they can get away with it. This is a very toxic and plastic environment. All the positive nonsense they feed you at orientation is just propaganda. I wouldn’t be surprised if half the positive reviews on here were just paid reviews to keep themselves out of hot water. Do yourself a favor and work somewhere where you’re not just another cog in the machine.
